q3.value:
Creativity has grown to be a major driver in the success of organizations (Zhou & Hoever, 2014). This has led to an increasing need to understand the underlying processes that promote creativity. One such process that has been found to strongly predict creativity is a person’s disposition to mindwander (Baird et al., 2012).
	Mindwandering has often been perceived as negative. However, recent research has revealed the potential positive consequences of mindwandering (Smallwood & Schooler, 2015; Smallwood & Andrews-Hana, 2013; Moneyham & Schooler, 2013; Watkins, 2008). Despite these strides in understanding positive mindwandering, discrepancies have emerged between experiencing mindwandering and creativity (Smeekens & Kane, 2016). Some of these discrepancies are differences in self-report versus probing measures (Smeekens & Kane, 2016) and others more related to the content of one’s mind (Tan, Zou, Chen, & Luo, 2016; Hao, Wu, Runco, & Pina, 2015;). 
This paper focuses on the latter through the lens of the content regulation hypothesis. This paper will examine how the emotions experienced during mindwandering may affect creative thinking. Emotions have already been found to influence creative thinking ability (Campion & Levita, 2013; Baas, Dreu, & Nistjad, 2008), but it may also regulate how mindwandering impacts a person’s ability to be creative.
By further understanding how the emotional content of mindwandering effects creativity, researchers may gain a greater understanding of when mindwandering may be positive or negative. This paper will examine creativity and how a new measure of creativity may help in answering this question. I will also discuss the content-regulation-hypothesis of mindwandering and emotions potential relationship. Finally, this paper proposes a correlational study to test the relationship between creativity, mindwandering and positive emotions.

q4.value: Emotions will moderate the relationship between creativity and midnwandering

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: For this study, 100 participants will be recruited through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk) to test the moderating relationship. Participants recruited through MTurk will be used because it has been found to produce data higher in external validity than other types of sampling methods without much additional cost (Buhrmester, Kwang, & Gosling,  2016). After signing consent forms, participants will take the forward flow free association task with the instructed seed word and proceed to fill out the 19 available lines. Participants will also have to complete 11 RAT problems and will fill out the PANAS-X, the daydreaming frequency scale and the intelligence questions. To control for any ordering effect, order will be randomly assigned in a partial design. counterbalanced PANAS-X and the daydreaming frequency scale will be regressed onto forward flow and RAT scores including an interaction effect.
Forward Flow, RAT, daydreaming scale, verbal skills, critical thinking and matrices tasks , emotions on the PANAS-X scale

attributes.title: How loyal is the party line?

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: How valid is the political party line? Modeling the relationship between political candidate transgression severity and ingroup party loyalty.

other.value:
Before administering the main survey, we piloted the 60 scenarios and collected severity ratings. For these ratings, we used the original method from the National Crime Survey (1985) in which participants were free to type in their own severity score, with no upper limit. To create overall ratings and rankings for they severity scores, we  will remove scores that do not possess an underlying normal distribution (or at least approaching one), and scores 2 standard deviations below and above the mean.  If scenarios do not sufficiently continuously increase in severity, scenario ratings will be transformed either using log base 10, or put in rank order.

Also, this is still a valid preregistration because half of the data that is already collected has not yet been examined. Data collection was started early to ensure that data was collected in time for an upcoming conference.

sample.value: We plan to collect data from 550 participants. Most of all, this is the greatest number of participants we could realistically afford. However, we needed at least 150 valid responses from Republican participants and 150 valid responses from Democratic participants to create models for each both groups. Because we did not have a way to specifically target conservative participants, we had to collect over 300 participants in order to ensure we obtained a sufficient number of conservative participants.

analyses.value: The data will be fit to a logistic regression model with random effects of political orientation, and fit indices will be examined. Further, the data for Republican participants and Democratic participants will each be fit to a separate model. Slopes and fit indices for the republican and democratic model will be compared.

outliers.value: Participants who fail attention checks will be removed from analysis.  Participants who identify as one political party at the start of the survey but vote for the opposing candidate for every scenario will be removed from analysis, as these participants either did not understand the study or were not paying attention to scenarios or directions. Because data is either yes/no, outliers with extreme responses will be hard to spot, and therefore we do not expect outliers in the traditional sense.

dependent.value: 1. Vote for ingroup candidate or outgroup candidate (A republican or democratic candidate): Participants will be presented with a scenario in which their ingroup candidate has committed a transgression, and they must make a choice to vote for their ingroup candidate or the outgroup candidate. Participants will complete 60 trials and therefore make 60 different voting choices.

conditions.value: Participants will not be assigned to any conditions. All participants will make voting decisions between their ingroup candidate who committed a transgression, and the outgroup candidate (who has not committed a transgression).

hypothesis.value: Regarding an election, how severe of a transgression does an ingroup political candidate need to commit in order for a person to abandon their vote for the ingroup, and vote for the outgroup candidate? In other words, what is the relationship between candidate transgression severity and ingroup loyalty? Is this relationship different for Republicans and Democrats? Specifically, we hypothesize a sigmoidal relationship between transgression severity and ingroup loyalty, such that people will remain loyal to ingroup candidates for even very severe transgressions, but will stop support once a "severity threshold", (or transitional point in the sigmoid curve) is met.  We hypothesize that Republicans will have a higher severity threshold than Democrats, such that the transitional point in the sigmoidal function will occur at a higher level of candidate transgression severity. We also hypothesize that more conservative participants will have a higher transgression severity threshold than more liberal participants. In essence, conservatives will be more loyal to their ingroup candidate.

If scenarios do not sufficiently continuously increase in severity, scenario ratings will be transformed either using log base 10, or put in rank order.

Also, this is still a valid preregistration because half of the data that is already collected has not yet been examined. Data collection was started early to ensure that data was collected in time for an upcoming conference.

Because data is either yes/no, outliers with extreme responses will be hard to spot, and therefore we do not expect outliers in the traditional sense.

Participants will complete 60 trials and therefore make 60 different voting choices.

We hypothesize that Republicans will have a higher severity threshold than Democrats, such that the transitional point in the sigmoidal function will occur at a higher level of candidate transgression severity. We also hypothesize that more conservative participants will have a higher transgression severity threshold than more liberal participants. In essence, conservatives will be more loyal to their ingroup candidate.

attributes.title: Oat beta-glucan and postprandial glycemia outcomes: a systematic review and meta-analysis of acute feeding trials

summary.value:
Title: Oat beta-glucan and postprandial glycemia outcomes: a systematic review and meta-analysis of acute feeding trials 

Organization: INQUIS Clinical Research, Ltd. 

Objective: Our objective is to synthesize the evidence of the dose response effect of the oat beta-glucan to available carbohydrate ratio on postprandial glucose and insulin responses. 

Searches: MEDLINE, Embase, and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials will be searched using appropriate search terms supplemented by manual searches of references of included studies. 

Participants/population: Participants of all health backgrounds will be included. 

Intervention(s), exposure(s): Any dose of oat beta-glucan or oat bran consumed with a carbohydrate containing-meal.

Comparator(s)/control: Carbohydrate-containing meal without the addition of oat beta-glucan or oat bran. 

Types of studies included: Randomized, controlled, acute feeding, crossover trials 

Main outcome(s): Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) for blood glucose, iAUC insulin, peak rise of glucose, peak rise of insulin 

Data extraction (selection and coding): Two investigators will independently extract relevant data. All disagreements will be resolved by consensus. Mean and standard errors (SEs) will be extracted for all outcomes. Standard computations and imputations will be used to derive missing data.

Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Two investigators will independently assess risk of bias and study quality using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool and a study quality tool developed for the research question. All disagreements will be resolved by consensus.

Data Analysis: Paired analyses will be applied to all crossover trials. Linear and non-linear dose response analyses will be conducted by meta-regression. Ratio of means will be pooled using the generic inverse variance method with random-effects models. Random-effects models will be used even in the absence of statistically significant between-study heterogeneity, as they yield more conservative summary effect estimates in the presence of residual heterogeneity. Fixed-effects models will only be used where there are less than 5 included trial comparisons. Heterogeneity will be tested (Cochran Q statistic) and quantified (I² statistic). To explore sources of heterogeneity, the investigators will conduct sensitivity analyses, in which each study is systematically removed. If there are more than 10 trial comparisons, then publication bias will be assessed by inspection of funnel plot and the Egger and Begg tests. If publication bias is suspected, then an adjustment for funnel plot asymmetry will be attempted by imputing the missing study data using the Duval and Tweedie trim-and-fill method. If there are more than 10 trial comparisons, then the investigators will explore sources of heterogeneity by a priori subgroup analyses by health status, dose, comparator, food form, duration of follow-up, risk of bias, and study quality.

Anticipated or actual start date: October 10, 2019 

Anticipated completion date: June 30, 2020 

Funding sources/sponsors: PepsiCo Global R&D

Participants/population: Participants of all health backgrounds will be included. 

Intervention(s), exposure(s): Any dose of oat beta-glucan or oat bran consumed with a carbohydrate containing-meal.

Comparator(s)/control: Carbohydrate-containing meal without the addition of oat beta-glucan or oat bran. 

Types of studies included: Randomized, controlled, acute feeding, crossover trials 

Main outcome(s): Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) for blood glucose, iAUC insulin, peak rise of glucose, peak rise of insulin 

Data extraction (selection and coding): Two investigators will independently extract relevant data. All disagreements will be resolved by consensus. Mean and standard errors (SEs) will be extracted for all outcomes. Standard computations and imputations will be used to derive missing data.

Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Two investigators will independently assess risk of bias and study quality using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool and a study quality tool developed for the research question. All disagreements will be resolved by consensus.

Data Analysis: Paired analyses will be applied to all crossover trials. Linear and non-linear dose response analyses will be conducted by meta-regression. Ratio of means will be pooled using the generic inverse variance method with random-effects models. Random-effects models will be used even in the absence of statistically significant between-study heterogeneity, as they yield more conservative summary effect estimates in the presence of residual heterogeneity. Fixed-effects models will only be used where there are less than 5 included trial comparisons. Heterogeneity will be tested (Cochran Q statistic) and quantified (I² statistic). To explore sources of heterogeneity, the investigators will conduct sensitivity analyses, in which each study is systematically removed. If there are more than 10 trial comparisons, then publication bias will be assessed by inspection of funnel plot and the Egger and Begg tests. Funding sources/sponsors: PepsiCo Global R&D

attributes.title: Online Endorsement Cues and the Political Conditioning of Factual Perceptions

q1.value: Online Endorsement Cues and the Political Conditioning of Factual Perceptions

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: In the increasingly-popular context of online social news aggregators, citizens face a media environment replete with cues. In addition to partisan heuristic activation, internet users frequently encounter peer endorsement cues such as the number of shares, `likes' or votes associated with content---signals which can indicate the utility of information to users. Less well-understood, however, are situations in which users confront partisan content in the presence of endorsement cues. In an online experiment, this study examines how endorsement cues condition partisans' reactions to supported and unsupported statements about the economy.

q16.value: The experimental treatments expose users to a simulated web interface called Vote4.com. The interface is designed to be similar to Reddit.com in appearance and functionality. Subjects are randomly assigned to receive one of five conditions, which consist of clickable posts in the second position of the simulated website's list of "most recent posts". Four treatments present positive information about the U.S. economy, while a fifth condition is a control condition (the post contains information about a rare plant). The treatment conditions are as follows: T1. No endorsement cue, supported argument T2. Endorsement cue, supported argument T3. No endorsement cue, unsupported argument T4. Endorsement cue, unsupported argument T5. No argument The study measures four key dependent variables: DV1. Whether a respondent 'votes' for the treatment story (equivalent to Facebook's 'like' or Reddit's 'upvote') [vote] DV2. The number of a respondent's clicks on the treatment interface [clicktot] DV3. Five-point economic retrospection battery [retro] DV4. Response to question "Based on the posts you saw earlier, would you be likely to learn accurate information from Vote4.com if you became a regular user of the site?" (Very likely, somewhat likely, neither likely nor unlikely, somewhat unlikely, very unlikely") [vote4acc] The expectations can be summarized by the following, where the > and < symbols indicate the direction of each expectation. Different expectations exist for Republicans and for Democrats. Test 1. treatment ~ vote Expectations: Democrats T1 > T5, T2 > T5, T3 > T5, T4 > T5 Expectations: Republicans T1 = T5, T2 > T5, T3 = T5, T4 = T5 Test 2. treatment ~ clicktot Expectations: Democrats T1 > T5, T2 >> T5, T3 > T5, T4 >> T5 Expectations: Republicans T1 = T5, T2 > T5, T3 = T5, T4 > T5 Test 3. treatment ~ retro Expectations: Democrats T1 > T5, T2 >> T5, T3 > T5, T4 >> T5 Expectations: Republicans T1 = T5, T2 > T5, T3 < T5, T4 T5, T2 >> T5, T3 > T5, T4 >> T5 Expectations: Republicans T1 < T5, T2

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using the R programming environment. First the hypotheses will be evaluated using the following interactive regression models: mod1

attributes.title: Party Building and Politician Defection in Zambia

q1.value: Party Building and Politician Defection in Zambia

q2.value: Leonardo Arriola | Lise Rakner | Donghyun Danny Choi | Justine M. Davis | Ingvild Aagedal Skage | Melanie L. Thompson

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We conduct a survey experiment of parliamentary candidates in Zambia. In the context of countries with nascent political party systems, the survey seeks to understand the factors influencing individual politicians in their choices over party affiliation and defection, leadership endorsements, campaign entry, campaign financing, and policy positions. Embedded in the survey is an experiment that uses randomized conjoint analysis. Drawing on hypotheses from the existing literature on political parties and African politics, we assess candidate preferences by asking respondents to choose their preferred party from among hypothetically generated pairs of parties.

q16.value: H1 (Party Structure): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that have a high level of party organization and institutionalization, with participatory mechanisms for the selection of the party leadership. H2 (National Voter Support): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that have a high level of voter support at the national level. H3a (Local Voter Support): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that have a high level of voter support in their own constituencies. H3b (Local Elite Support): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that are supported by local power elites such as tribal chiefs, religious leaders, and headmen. H4 (Candidate Selection): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that have bottom-up processes of candidate selection such as primary elections. H5a (Incentives - Campaign Financing): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that offer support for campaign finances. H5b (Incentives - Government Appointments): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that promise future cabinet and subcabinet appointments. H5c (Incentives - Guaranteed Nominations): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that guarantee party nomination for the constituency for which they are seeking office. H6 (Relationship with party leaders): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties in which they share social ties with the party leader. H7: Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that currently control the executive branch.

q17.value: We use conjoint analysis to test hypotheses derived from the existing literature. We present respondents with two profiles of hypothetical parties generated from eight attributes, and we ask them to make a choice between them.

registration_responses.q1: Party Building and Politician Defection in Zambia
registration_responses.q2: Leonardo Arriola | Lise Rakner | Donghyun Danny Choi | Justine M. Davis | Ingvild Aagedal Skage | Melanie L. Thompson
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: We conduct a survey experiment of parliamentary candidates in Zambia. In the context of countries with nascent political party systems, the survey seeks to understand the factors influencing individual politicians in their choices over party affiliation and defection, leadership endorsements, campaign entry, campaign financing, and policy positions. Embedded in the survey is an experiment that uses randomized conjoint analysis. Drawing on hypotheses from the existing literature on political parties and African politics, we assess candidate preferences by asking respondents to choose their preferred party from among hypothetically generated pairs of parties.
registration_responses.q16: H1 (Party Structure): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that have a high level of party organization and institutionalization, with participatory mechanisms for the selection of the party leadership. H2 (National Voter Support): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that have a high level of voter support at the national level. H3a (Local Voter Support): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that have a high level of voter support in their own constituencies. H3b (Local Elite Support): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that are supported by local power elites such as tribal chiefs, religious leaders, and headmen. H4 (Candidate Selection): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that have bottom-up processes of candidate selection such as primary elections. H5a (Incentives - Campaign Financing): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that offer support for campaign finances. H5b (Incentives - Government Appointments): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that promise future cabinet and subcabinet appointments. H5c (Incentives - Guaranteed Nominations): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that guarantee party nomination for the constituency for which they are seeking office. H6 (Relationship with party leaders): Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties in which they share social ties with the party leader. H7: Candidates are more likely to prefer political parties that currently control the executive branch.
registration_responses.q17: We use conjoint analysis to test hypotheses derived from the existing literature. We present respondents with two profiles of hypothetical parties generated from eight attributes, and we ask them to make a choice between them.

attributes.title: Institutional Trust, Identity, and Compliance in Guinea

q1.value: Institutional Trust, Identity, and Compliance in Guinea

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In many weakly democratized states, citizens place little trust in state institutions. However, in moments of public health crises, citizens must often turn to states they do not trust in order to obtain essential services. To understand the sources of compliance and resistance with public health advisories, we use a survey-based experiment that examines how varying levels of citizen trust in government affect compliance with directives from different authority sources. The experimental manipulation is administered by varying the identity of the authority figure — i.e., a national president, an international organization, a local government official, and a traditional authority figure — in a short vignette that presents a hypothetical public health crisis and ensuing demand.

q16.value: By disaggregating which institutions citizens trust and their willingness to engage with different kinds institutions, we seek to advance our understanding on how governmental and international interventions in future public health crises might be improved. We anticipate that citizens who feel politically alienated or disenfranchised are less likely to report a willingness to comply with directives from state authorities. Specifically: H1: Respondents who report less trust in state institutions are likely to exhibit greater willingness to comply with demands of religious leaders. H2: Respondents who report less trust in state institutions are likely to exhibit greater willingness to comply with demands of traditional leaders. H3: Respondents who report less trust in state institutions are likely to exhibit less willingness to comply with demands of the sous-préfét. H4: Respondents who report less trust in state institutions are likely to exhibit less willingness to comply with demands of the president. H5: Respondents who report less trust in state institutions are likely to exhibit greater willingness to comply with demands of an international organization. H6: Respondents who report less trust in state institutions are likely to exhibit less willingness to use a health center run by the government. H7: Respondents who report less trust in state institutions are likely to exhibit greater willingness to use a health center run by international organizations. H8: Respondents who report less trust in state institutions are likely to exhibit greater willingness to use a traditional healer. H9: Respondents are more likely to comply with the demands of authorities they perceive to care about people like them. H10: Respondents are more likely to comply with the demands of authorities they have contacted at least once in the past 12 months. H11: Respondents who report that their ethnic group is persecuted by the state will be more likely to comply with demands of religious and traditional leaders and less likely to comply with demands from the President. H12: Respondents will report greater willingness to comply with representatives from international organizations if they self report the presence of international organizations in their community during the response to Ebola In terms of heterogeneous treatment effects, we expect to find that effects vary according to 1) respondents’ self-identified ethnicity; 2) rural and urban sub-samples; and 3) location in Labé and Kindia prefectures.

q17.value: We will pursue an intention-to-treat analysis. We will compare average responses among respondents randomly assigned to treatment and control conditions, using standard two-sided difference-in-means tests, with an alpha of 0.05.

attributes.title: Internet Service Provision under Authoritarian Rule: A Field Experiment in Belarus

q1.value: Internet Service Provision under Authoritarian Rule: A Field Experiment in Belarus

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The global expansion of digital communication, in particular the Internet, has opened up new channels of political debate and mobilization. Many argue that this should have a particularly profound impact in autocracies, where traditional media are often under strict control by the government. With government censorship becoming more difficult in the digital realm, social media are assumed to provide new opportunities for regime-critical discussion, exposure of government abuse, and coordination for collective action. These opportunities, however, have not gone unnoticed by autocratic governments. This is why an emerging literature in comparative politics studies the various ways in which dictators respond to the potential threats arising from the expansion of the Internet. One obvious strategy a regime can employ is to shape digital content in its favor. This can be done either by eliminating unwanted content, or by producing content that is explicitly supportive of the regime. Other approaches autocratic governments can pursue target the underlying network infrastructure. For example, at the height of the Tahir Square protest, Hosni Mubarak of Egypt shut down the country's Internet, supposedly to prevent further escalation. Both digital censorship and Internet shutdowns can entail significant risks for dictators: Censorship may be imperfect, such that the regime is unable to eliminate a large share of potentially threatening information. Shutting down the entire infrastructure also has important drawbacks, as it affects not only government opponents but also supporters, while at the same time cutting off Internet services also for government agencies. This is why recent research suggests that autocratic governments can pursue a different strategy: Rather than first providing Internet services and then having to (i) censor them at a high cost or (ii) turn them off entirely, it should be much more beneficial to make the provision of Internet service selective: governments afraid of dissent and mobilization catalyzed by the Internet should be hesitant to provide potential challengers with Internet services. This should significantly reduce the need to censor (since regime-critical content would be less likely to be produced and read), but also the need for large infrastructure shutdowns (since the challengers would be less likely to use the Internet anyway). We conduct a field experiment in Belarus to examine whether governments do strategical limit the Internet access of the political opposition.

q16.value: H1: The regime should limit the Internet access of the political opposition.

q17.value: We test this hypothesis by contacting Beltelecom, the state-owned telephone and Internet service provider, with requests for technical assistance. We randomly vary two factors. The first factor is the political affiliation of the sender. The sender can be pro-regime (indicated by a pro-regime quote in the signature), anti-regime (indicated by an anti-regime quote in the signature), or unaffiliated (indicated by the absence of a quote in the signature). We also vary the type of request. The putative sender either requests assistance with their Internet service or their domestic phone service. We do this to examine whether Beltelecom agents are simply anti-opposition or whether they want to selectively limit the opposition's Internet access. See attached pre-analysis plan for additional details.

q23.value: Received permission to proceed. No IRB number to report.

attributes.title: The Impact of Officers Wearing Body Cameras: A Field Experiment from Washington D.C.

q1.value: The Impact of Officers Wearing Body Cameras: A Field Experiment from Washington D.C.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: There has been a recent influx of police officers wearing body cameras across the United States. Given this new phenomena it is important what kind of impact it is having on citizens perceptions of police officers. This study tests that notion.

q16.value: How Body Worn Cameras change the level of officer accountability, citizen satisfaction and trust between citizens and police officers.

q17.value: I will offer three surveys to residents in Washington D.C.

attributes.title: Overcoming Exclusion: Intergroup Contact and Prosocial Behavior Among Roma and non-Roma in Slovenia

q1.value: Overcoming Exclusion: Intergroup Contact and Prosocial Behavior Among Roma and non-Roma in Slovenia

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This project explores the social exclusion of Roma (commonly known by the disfavored term “Gypsies”). I examine how Roma and non-Roma interact in a public goods setting and test whether NGO-promoted intergroup contact is associated with more cooperative behaviors of both groups. To conduct this test, I collect data from two towns in Slovenia that match exceptionally well on twelve local/regional Roma and human rights-related factors, but differ in type of NGO action. Action in the first town, Murska Sobota, is inclusive—targeting both Roma and non-Roma—and promotes intergroup contact. NGO action in the second town, Novo mesto, is non-inclusive and focuses on service provision to Romani settlements. This pre-analysis plan was registered while fieldwork was ongoing. The author had access to some but not all of the outcome data. Registration occurred before analysis.

q16.value: The chief comparison is between behaviors of Roma and non-Roma from Murska Sobota (intergroup contact NGO action) and Roma and non-Roma from Novo mesto (service provision NGO). I hypothesize that non-Roma from Murska Sobota will contribute no more and no less to the public good in the mixed ethnic condition than they do in the coethnic condition, but that non-Roma from Novo mesto will contribute more in the coethnic condition. I also hypothesize that the Roma from both locations will contribute more in the coethnic condition. I further hypothesize that Roma will be more likely to contribute to the public good when all other players are contributing at a high rate. I hypothesize that in indirectly rewarding prosocial behavior, Roma will reward coethnics more than non-coethnics, and that the same will hold for non-Roma in Novo mesto. I hypothesize that non-Roma from Murska Sobota will reward non-Roma no more and no less than they reward the Roma.

q17.value: I collect the data on cooperation using a public goods game and a survey in two Slovene towns, Murska Sobota and Novo mesto. The design uses a combination of a 12-round public goods game and indirect reciprocity, delivered as a video game. The video game delivery is necessary because Roma and non-Roma are quite reluctant to participate in the same room, and because subsets of Romani populations have low levels of literacy. The video game allows subjects to participate in private, without having to read. Roma and non-Roma participants play the game with 7 simulated other players who represent coethnic and ethnically mixed scenarios of varying levels of cooperation. I use a within subject design in the games; every participant plays all the conditions, which are randomly ordered (with the exception of the baseline condition, which is played first). No deception is used; participants are told they are playing with a computer, but that the computer’s decisions are based on those of real people in their towns (from data collected in pilot rounds). I use stratified random sampling to recruit participants from 1) the Romani settlements (Roma) and 2) the main part of town (non-Roma).
